body: After I hit :q in terminal neovim, even when I closed my terminal, in activity monitor, I can still see nvim is using 100% of my cpu. I am using iterm2. Mac 10.11. What is going on?

comment_data.body: select nvim, click the gear icon, select "sample process". Then please paste the result here or in a gist.
I killed the process already. Let me try duplicate this situation again.

I have run into this issue a couple times, and I think it tends to be after I've used the built-in terminal. Here's the output from sampling the process:

Interesting, it is stuck in `process_teardown()`. @justinnhli what is `:version` ?

```
Press ENTER or type command to continue
```
To be clear, my issue may be slightly different from that of @ranranking. I don't think nvim takes up 100% CPU in this state, but it does continue running in iTerm until I Crtl+C.
@justinnhli Does it ever complete if you wait a long time without ctrl-c?
I got the sample around the 10min mark. I'll keep it running the next time it happens and report back.
Oh, 10min is long enough, don't trouble yourself :)
I finally got the same issue today, and this is my sample process
And it's using over 100% of my cpu again

Today, I got this several times. Mostly are related to :terminal and :so ~/.vimrc. Both of these two commands, especially the second one which source the vimrc file, can trigger this problem. At first, nvim would crash, I can not make any movements anymore, then I can only close my terminal and nvim keeps running, using up 100% of my cpu and more. here is another sample file:
[Sample of nvim 2.txt](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/files/156217/Sample.of.nvim.2.txt)
@ranranking If you can provide a minimal vimrc that reproduces the issue, that would be really helpful. Also, what `:version` ?
OK! I will try to make it, although even with my current vimrc, I don't know the exact way to reproduce the crash! My version is 0.1.2, homebrew installed.

I finally figured out how to reproduce this problem. This is my vimrc file:

``` vim
  set runtimepath+=~/.vim/dein/repos/github.com/Shougo/dein.vim

  call dein#begin(expand('~/.vim/dein'))

  call dein#add('Shougo/dein.vim', {'rtp':''})

  call dein#add('AndrewRadev/switch.vim', {'on_map':['<c-s>']})
  call dein#add('tomtom/tcomment_vim', {'on_map': ['g','v']})
  call dein#end()

  map <S-J> 10gj
  map <S-K> 10gk

  nnoremap <Leader>rl :so ~/.vimrc<CR>
```

To reproduce it, you use neovim to open this .vimrc file, create a new line, save the file, use `:so ~/.vimrc` to reload the file, and then you have to delete one blank line, save it, and source the file again. Then, when you hit `S-J` or `S-K` you will find the program crashed. I could only kill it from outside. The two packages are necessary in my situation, the map `<leader>rl` is also nessary. Whether other package manager can lead to the same problem I don't know, at least I had the same problem when I was still using Neobundle. The `<S-J>` and `<S-K>` are used to trigger the problem. In fact, when there are more plugins and more vim settings, I could get this problem simply by making any modifications to the file, save it and reload it, the program will crash. I didn't have to save and reload twice by creating and deleting a line. But this is the minimal .vimrc I could have. Although I am using a more complicated way to trigger the crash, I think these crashes may lead to the same problem.

And, please create the blank line at the end of the file and delete the same line. I realized that sometimes, if you create the new line elsewhere, the crash won't be triggered. If the crash is not happening, please do the line creating and deleting more times, and hit `S-J` or `S-K` more times.

> To be clear, my issue may be slightly different from that of @ranranking. I don't think nvim takes up 100% CPU in this state, but it does continue running in iTerm until I Crtl+C.

@justinnhli, do you still have this problem when using a newer version of nvim?
@ranranking, I cannot reproduce a crash with the script you have given. Can you still reproduce this problem with a newer version of nvim?
@oni-link I _think_ it's still happening but, like before, it's intermittent. For the purpose of this issue, feel free to close it; I'll open a new issue if I can reproduce it reliably.

title: Neovim keeps running after I closed it in terminal
